event.title: Starting Point
event.content: Please select a country. For testing purpose only!

event.messageBoxA: Welcome, %gender% %surname%. I am very glad that you decided to accept our job offer as my Management Assistant as your first job after receiving your bachelor degree. I hope everything was to your convenience in your first week at our company. We would like to throw you in at the deep end and send you to our subsidiary in South Africa. You will be working with Dr. Dieter Schmidt, a Senior Project Manager. Currently, he is engaged in the year end closing. He has been already in the subsidiary in Pretoria for 2 weeks. You will be his Project Assistant. Good luck!

event.description: ... 2 days later you're sitting on the plane to Pretoria ...
... because you were stuck more than an hour in traffic, you're already 20 minutes late for the project meeting when you enter the conference room ...

event.messageBoxA: Oh, hello %gender% %surname%. We have already started our meeting. Please sit down. Maybe you can present yourself at the end of the meeting to the project team? We are running out of time!
event.messageBoxB: You sit down as Mr. Schmidt told you and you’ll present yourself at the end of the meeting.
You say: "Good morning everyone, I'm %prename% %surname%" and you sit down.

You ignore his request and present yourself: "Good morning everyone, I'm %prename% %surname%. I'm from Germany like my colleague Dr. Dieter Schmidt and I'm here to support him. I hope we will have a good and successful year end closing."

event.messageBoxA: Hello %gender% %surname%. I'm Mr. Asomoa and I'm the CEO of this subsidiary. We are glad that you joined our project team. By the way, it’s almost lunch time and you’re probably exhausted of your journey. We want to watch the cricket match of our local team together in 2 hours. If you want, we can go to a nice bar now, get some food and watch the game. We can talk about business tomorrow. Do you like cricket?
event.messageBoxB: Yes, I like cricket but I've never played it before.
No, I've never heard of cricket. What is it?
No, I don’t like it at all. For me it's nothing more than a strange type of sport.

event.messageBoxA: Nobody cares about cricket!
event.messageBoxB: Excuse me Mr. Schmidt, we want to get to know %gender% %surname%. I think we can talk about business later.
event.messageBoxA: It's still Dr. Schmidt and I want to get my work done. We don't have any time for silly get together games. However, let me see the reports now?
event.messageBoxB: I'm terribly sorry, but I haven't prepared any files yet. So let me...
event.messageBoxA: WHAT? WHY NOT? You must be kidding. Haven’t you been informed about the importance of this project? Your subsidiary is the only one within our group without any finished financial statements. Last week you told me you will be ready this week. But in fact you’re not... I can't believe it. Do you not know the purpose of my visit? Your subsidiary is really good for nothing.
event.messageBoxB: Okay… That’s enough. I need a break.

event.description: ... Mr. Asamoa leaps from his chair and leaves the room ...
... One hour later you receive a call from Germany ...
event.messageBoxA: What’s going on? Mr. Asamoa just called and threatens to resign. I have to withdraw you from the running project. Come back immediately, I want you in my office by tomorrow.

event.description: ... One day later at your boss's office ...

event.messageBoxA: As I told you on the phone, things went terribly wrong. Mr. Asamoa was very offended and refused to keep working in the existing team. Now, tell me from your perspective. What happened in South Africa?
event.messageBoxB: Mr. Asamoa wouldn’t stop talking about cricket instead of finally starting to get things done. There was no progress at all.
Mr. Schmidt was quite rude. Instead of just listening to the cricket stories and adapting at least a little, he wanted to get things done his way.
It felt like nobody was willing to adapt his behaviour. So we couldn’t really start working at all! But I can’t really tell you why this happened.

event.messageBoxA: Okay, thank you %gender% %surname%, I understand. In order to prevent this from happening again, we will offer an Intercultural Management training to all of our employees. Do you want to participate?
event.messageBoxB: Start Intercultural Management training.
Skip Intercultural Management training.

event.messageBoxA: You want to skip the intercultural training? Are you sure about this?
event.messageBoxB: Yes, I read some articles online and I am pretty sure about what went wrong in Africa.
I really don’t know… Maybe you are right. I don’t want to mess things up. Can I still take the training?

event.messageBoxA: Well, ok. Usually I wanted to give you some time in Germany to setup yourself at this location. But things often go differently than planned… We’ve got some issues in several locations all over the world. Your assistance is needed! But at least you can decide where you want to go first… These are the projects that I am talking about. Please pick your next destination out of the country selection drop down menu.
Of course! Your training takes place in room 021.

event.title: WorldMap
event.description: Where on the Cultural World Map is Germany?

event.description26: Give it a try! Rate Germany in each of the 9 Dimensions.

event.title: Intercultural Management

option.title: being able to create and keep relationships based on mutual trust

event.option: being able to create and keep relationships based on mutual trust

event.title: Communication
event.description: Your partner's statement: There is no milk in the fridge!
event.option: I want to drink some milk now.
Go to the supermarket and buy some milk.

event.title: Percentage of non-verbal communication
event.content: What do you think is the percentage of non verbal communication?

event.title: Percentage of non-verbal communication
event.content: This answer is not correct. The percentage of non-verbal communication is about 70-80%.

event.title: Percentage of non-verbal communication
event.content: Your answer is correct. The percentage of non-verbal communication is about 70-80%.

event.messageBoxA: Hello, %gender% %surname%. So you finished your training. Do you feel like the training helped you to be more comfortable while working in an intercultural environment?
event.messageBoxB: Yes, of course. The training helped me a lot to understand what was going wrong in South Africa.
Yes, I guess… Most things were pretty obvious though…
No, not really… It was kind of boring...

event.messageBoxA: Well, we’ll see pretty soon whether the training was really helpful. Usually I wanted to give you some time in Germany to setup yourself at this location. But things often go differently than planned… We’ve got some issues in several locations all over the world. Your assistance is needed! But at least you can decide where you want to go first… These are the projects that I am talking about. Please pick your next destination out of the country selection drop down menu.

event.message: You have successfully completed the Tutorial! Congratulations!

event.description: Please select the square to which you would assign Brazil to!

event.description26: Give it a try! Rate Brazil in each of the 9 dimensions.

event.content:
Shortly before the landing a short video about Brazil is shown on the seat-back screen in front of you.
Just lean back and enjoy!

You have finally arrived in São Paulo after a long and exhausting flight. Danilo, one of the employees of Tyron Technologies picks you up at the airport. You already know this man from phone conversations you had when you were still back home. On the phone, you really got on well. He is already impatiently waiting for you in the arrival hall. How do you think he will welcome you?
event.option: It will be strict handshaking between the two of us.
Both of us just wave hands, smile and say hello in a friendly way.
It could happen that he hugs me, touches my arm/shoulder or gives me a light slap on the back.
He will give me a little kiss on the cheek.

event.message: This may occur, but it could also happen that a person touches you on your arm, shoulder or back in order to warmly welcome you.
This is rather unlikely to happen, since the Brazilian mentality includes a lot of body contact (between hierarchically equals).
Good answer, this indeed may happen.
This form of welcoming someone is indeed common between business people (man - woman, woman - woman) but only if they know each other already.

event.partner: Transport to hotel in co-worker's car
event.content: Danilo, befriended, as is usual with him, helps you with your luggage and gives you a lift to your accommodation. As the airport is a 40 minute ride away from your hotel, you two have plenty of time to have your first real face-to-face chat. While Danilo heaves your suitcase into the car trunk, you set your wits to work in order to think of special topics you two could have a conversation about.

event.title: Transport to hotel in co-worker's car
event.description: What, in your opinion are topics you can address in Brazil? Drag and drop the topics in the appropriate columns. In total 4 topics should be avoided during the conversation.

event.message: Too many personal questions should be avoided during conversation, especially regarding family, income and status in the workplace. It is better to talk about the Brazilian culture like dancing, football or traveling.

event.partner: Invitation by your colleague to pub night
event.content:
Your new colleague Danilo finally drops you off at your hotel.
As you got along quite well during the car ride, he spontaneously asks you:

event.description: Invitation by your colleague to pub night
event.messageBoxA: What about having dinner tonight. You could try some Brazilian specialities. I know a very good place called 'Damas'. Me and my colleagues go there nearly every week.
event.messageBoxB: Thank you for asking, but I am still totally exhausted from the flight and a bit groggy. I really would like to unpack my stuff first and do all that organizational kind of things.
event.messageBoxA: (He looks at you, slowly nods his head, hesitates a little bit and eventually says) Oh, are you sure? ... Well, fine then... See you tomorrow.

option.description: I am disappointed that you don’t want to join.
I wanted to get to know you better.
It is a pity but I accept that you do not come along.

event.message: Correct! Brazilians value socializing a lot, so he will rather not be too happy about you refusing his well-meant offer. Still, it is likely that he will not show you that he feels a little bit offended or he thinks you don’t want to be integrated socially.

event.description: Preparing for your first day at work!
event.message: You have slept well in your hotel bed the first night and had to get up early this morning. You find yourself standing in front of the wardrobe now. It is your first working day and you have to choose what you are going to wear today.

event.title: You have brought all kind of clothes, casual stuff, suits/dresses and sportswear. Select a proper dress for your first day at work.

event.message: Sorry, but this sort of casual outfit is not formal enough and you should avoid appearing in the office looking as if you were on holiday.
Correct. Most offices welcome and prefer an elegant business outfit even though the weather is hot.
A long-sleeve shirt is okay, but jeans are too informal.

event.content: In the end you decided to wear a nice suit today because you are about to meet the boss, Claudio Pires, on your first day. You arrive at the office at 9:00am where you are welcomed by his secretary.

event.messageBoxA: Good Morning %prename%, I hope you had a good flight. My name is Julia. Unfortunately, Senhor Pires has an important business meeting at short notice, that’s why he asked me to show you a little around and introduce you to your new colleagues.
event.messageBoxB: Good Morning Julia, nice to meet you. Oh, that’s fine. Thanks, I’ve had a pleasant journey. I’m looking forward to meet my new colleagues.

event.content: She shows you your workspace in the huge open space office. In the meantime, the other colleagues Maria, Carmen, Juan and Fernando join you and introduce themselves.

event.partner: Getting in touch with Senhor Pires
event.content: You’re a little overwhelmed and not quite sure how to get in contact with the boss to arrange a new meeting. What could you possibly do to get in touch with him for a first meeting?
event.option: I ask Maria for the boss' email address and write him a polite email.
I ask Juan for the boss' direct dialing number.
I ask Julia, the secretary, to arrange a new meeting with Senhor Pires.

event.message: It is not too common to write emails in Brazil. You wouldn’t especially email your boss, as you might never receive an answer. Best is to arrange a meeting via his secretary.
Juan makes you aware of that it is not common to directly contact your boss in Brazil. He offers you to bring you to the boss' secretary to announce your arrival.

A lot of Brazilian managers have their own office assistant (secretary in the outer office) to receive employees or guests. Right answer! You better let the assistant arrange for a meeting with the boss.

event.content: Oh, it’s already 9:40am and your first meeting with the project team is scheduled for 10:00am! So you hurry back to your desk to study your notes you prepared for the first meeting. On your way you run into Danilo, your Brazilian colleague who welcomed you at the airport. You say “hi” and he greets you back, however, he doesn’t seem to be in the mood to talk to you. It comes to your mind that he might be a little upset because you rejected his invitation for dinner yesterday. What could you do to make up for it?
event.option: When I see him again, I'll apologize for my behavior and explain to him that I didn’t think about the effects it could have, being considered rude. In the end, I'll invite him for a drink.

I have a lot of important stuff to do, so I decide to write an email to Danilo, explaining my behavior and apologizing for it. That should be sufficient as that incident wasn’t that big a deal at all.

In my opinion I didn’t do anything wrong. I don’t feel like I have to apologize for anything. I was really exhausted after the flight and Danilo should know that. I stop thinking about the event and start concentrating myself on more important tasks.

event.message: Danilo will most likely accept your apology. Brazilians in general are very generous and warm-hearted. They will easily forgive you a mistake you made when you talk to them directly.

An apology is no topic that you should put in writing in form of an email. Brazilians prefer verbal communication. That is why you should always try to talk to people directly and avoid writing emails if possible.

In Brazil everything is about relationships. People and their relations are considered much more important than anything else. It is very important for Brazilians to get to know the people they are working with. Therefore, you should take every opportunity you get to enhance your relationship with the locals.

event.content: After seeing Danilo you finally return to your desk. Quickly grabbing your notes, you go to the meeting room. It is your first meeting with the project team. As the decision to send you to Brazil was very spontaneous, you didn’t have the time to talk to the other project members beforehand. Nonetheless, you’ve already been reading through the project information during your flight and you took down some notes and ideas. You think you are well prepared and, therefore, you have a good feeling for the first meeting. What are your expectations for the meeting?
event.option: Everyone will shortly explain their role in the company and afterwards we’ll directly get to work talking about the current state of the project and everyone’s ideas in order to develop a project roadmap.
My Brazilian colleagues will start to talk about their past weekend, soccer... In general, everything but not the project. They seem very eager to get to know me and will ask me a lot of questions.

event.message: Brazilians do not tend to directly start talking about business. It is normal to have a little bit of small talk before starting the real meeting, especially when someone new joins the team. They want to establish a relationship with the people before they start working with them.
Correct! Brazilians want to know more about the people they work with. Before getting to business, they try to get to know their business partners or new team members.

event.content: During the project meeting you got the impression that Fernando is not really interested in the project. He seems somewhat unmotivated which is reflected in his work results. You think that you should find out why he’s lacking motivation and talk to him about his performance.
event.option: I'll address Fernando’s performance during the next project meeting. Maybe the others can give him some feedback as well and together we can encourage Fernando to improve his work.

After the next project meeting I'll take Fernando aside and signal him that I would like to talk to him in private. I'll ask him how the project is going and if there is anything I can support him with.

The next time I see Fernando I'll directly confront him with his poor work results. I'll tell him that his performance seems to be quite weak and ask him if he has any issues with his work where I might help him.

event.message: Try to avoid open, direct feedback or criticism. When you want to give someone feedback you should do it in a private conversation and not in front of the whole team as that causes the person to lose face.
Correct! Talk “between the lines”. Always stress the positive aspects! Make suggestions using the interrogative form. Avoid anything that could damage the relationship.

Try to avoid open, direct feedback or criticism. Talk “between the lines”. Always stress the positive aspects! Make suggestions using the interrogative form. Avoid anything that could damage the relationship.

You have scheduled a meeting with the project team for 10:00am in order to discuss the current as-is-situation and talk about possible measurements and follow-up activities. Unfortunately, it is already 10:00am and you are still the only attendee in the conference room. You start to get impatient and upset because you have quite a few meetings scheduled for the day and you do not want to be behind time after the first meeting! At around 10:15am the first team members start to show up. They welcome you kindly and take a seat. You, however, are not sure how to address your colleagues and stress the importance of punctuality. After everyone has finally arrived at 10:30am, you give the following speech...

event.title: During a meeting
event.description: Create the speech by putting the sentences in the right order via drag-and-drop (5 sentences are correct and 5 are wrong).

option.title: Hello everyone, I have to admit that I am quite disappointed.

event.option: Hello everyone, I have to admit that I am quite disappointed.

option.title: Hello everyone, I would like to welcome you to this meeting today.

event.option: Hello everyone, I would like to welcome you to this meeting today.

option.title: I thought we agreed to have a meeting on 10:00am and now it it already 10:30am.

event.option: I thought we agreed to have a meeting on 10:00am and now it is already 10:30am.

option.title: I am really looking forward to the next couple of months working together with you, therefore I suggest that we all agree to some basic rules, which we as a team need to follow.

event.option: I am really looking forward to the next couple of months working together with you, therefore I suggest that we all agree to some basic rules, which we as a team need to follow.

option.title: In order to make this project a success, it is important that we all commit ourselves to team work. With respect to other colleagues, who might have other meetings scheduled for the day, I suggest, for instance, that we meet deadlines.

event.option: In order to make this project a success, it is important that we all commit ourselves to team work. With respect to other colleagues, who might have other meetings scheduled for the day, I suggest, for instance, that we meet deadlines.

option.title: I would appreciate if you could try to make it on time, so that neither of us is running late for their next meetings.

event.option: I would appreciate if you could try to make it on time, so that neither of us is running late for their next meetings.

option.title: I actually had quite a few important meetings scheduled for today, which I now have to reschedule due to this delay.

event.option: I actually had quite a few important meetings scheduled for today, which I now have to reschedule due to this delay.

option.title: If we have the feeling that we are running late, we inform our teammates.

event.option: If we have the feeling that we are running late, we inform our teammates.

option.title: Thank you, anyway, I am really looking forward to the next couple of months working together with you.

event.option: Thank you, anyway, I am really looking forward to the next couple of months working together with you.

option.title: In this way, we are informed, the other teammates can go to their other scheduled meetings on time and we will give the person who was running late a brief update afterwards. What do you think you about that? Do you have any suggestions?

event.option: In this way, we are informed, the other teammates can go to their other scheduled meetings on time and we will give the person who was running late a brief update afterwards. What do you think you about that? Do you have any suggestions?

event.message: Great! Punctuality is a variable commodity. Meetings can start and finish late. Therefore, try to finish one meeting per day but with clear focus on things. Do not overload the team with activities right away – give time for team building.

event.content: After you have explained your teammates how important it is for you to start on time, they get your point and ensure you that they will consider this next time. Now, however, you seem to face another issue: Instead of talking about the business, your teammates talk about personal things (weather, weekend, etc.). You react as follows:
event.option: “...so anyway, I hope you had a good morning so far. For my part, I feel very lucky to get to experience this kind of weather at that time of year (note: February due to carnival season).”
“...so, considering the fact that we have already lost enough time, I suggest that we get straight to the point.”

“... Unfortunately I see that we have a tight schedule and yet a lot of things to discuss. Hence, I suggest that we try to work our way through and make a lunch break at 12:30pm in order to get some fresh air and catch up a little bit.”

event.message: This answer is quite likely, however, it does not show any appreciation of your teammates.
This way of reacting should better be avoided as it sounds quite harsh and your teammates can feel offended.
This is a very good way to push the meeting forward on the one hand, and on the other hand to maintain a good and solid relationship with your teammates by meeting for lunch.

event.content: Meetings start and end with a lot of small talk. Provide enough time and space for small talk. This strengthens your relationship and improves business.

You are discussing the new marketing concept for the region. When talking about the posters, their layout and content and responsibilities, you notice that most colleagues (especially Maria and Carmen, who have been working in the marketing department for 10 years now and have really good experience in this field) are very eager to contribute and share their ideas among their peers. One colleague, Fernando, who is the nephew of the Brazilian CEO, is not very participating in the discussions. While you are still contemplating who to assign the role of the manager for the marketing concept, your boss, Senhor Pires, spontaneously joins in. After he has picked up the current situation, he decides to give Fernando the responsibility to supervise the project including the work of Maria and Carmen, who have done most of the work so far. You cannot quite understand your boss’s decision. Why do you think your boss put Fernando in charge?
event.option: Senhor Pires does not trust Maria and Carmen due to their lack of experience.
He wants to give Fernando the chance in order to please the CEO.
He prefers men over women in leading positions.

event.message: This answer is unlikely as both women have the trust of the boss and are reliable employees. However, social aspects outweigh performance in many cases. Hierarchy plays quite an important role in Brazil. It is important to show respect to the hierarchically superior. In companies, the bosses often assume the role of a “good parent”. Moreover, Brazil scores high in Collectivism. For instance, an older and powerful member of a family is expected to “help” a younger nephew to be hired for a job in his own company.

Correct! In Brazil it is important to show respect to the hierarchically superior. In companies, the bosses often assume the role of a “good parent”. Moreover, Brazil scores high in Collectivism. For instance, an older and powerful member of a family is expected to “help” a younger nephew to be hired for a job in his own company.

The answer could be true, but Maria and Carmen already have been working for 10 years in the company and they already earned the trust of their boss. However, hierarchy plays quite an important role in Brazil. In Brazil it is important to show respect to the hierarchically superior. In companies, the bosses often assume the role of a “good parent”. Moreover, Brazil scores high in Collectivism. For instance, an older and powerful member of a family is expected to “help” a younger nephew to be hired for a job in his own company.

event.content: While discussing the deadline for the aforementioned marketing campaign, you are rather interested in the long-term outcome and talk about possible milestones during the next 6 months, your team members only consider the next three weeks. After the meeting is over, Juan and you pack your stuff and prepare to leave until a question comes to your mind:

event.messageBoxA: Juan, I know that everyone is working quite hard to make this new marketing campaign a success, however, I cannot quite see an added value, if we are only considering the next three weeks ahead of us? Shouldn’t we make our decisions based on long-term considerations?
event.messageBoxB: %prename%, I can understand your concern, however, I also think that this is a matter of perception. We in Brazil often tempt to make decisions in a more flexible and short matter. This does not mean that we are not well-enough prepared though, in case unforeseen things happen or we need to make changes. We work just as hard as people who plan three or six months in advance, we just set our focus a bit differently...

event.title: Long-term vs. short-term
event.description: Considering the aforementioned different perceptions of long-term vs. short-term orientation, please allocate the following characteristics in the corresponding columns.

option.title: face considerations common but seen as a weakness

event.option: face considerations common but seen as a weakness

option.title: higher focus on tasks and issues than on relationships

event.option: higher focus on tasks and issues than on relationships

option.title: traditions are adaptable to changed circumstances

event.option: traditions are adaptable to changed circumstances

event.content: Well done! Long-term orientation describes countries which are mainly focused on the future. People with this cultural perspective value abilities such as perseverance, persistence, saving and adaptability. They are more likely to delay short-term success or gratification in order to prepare for the future.

Short-term orientation describes countries which are mainly focused on the present or past and consider them more important than the future. People with this cultural perspective value tradition, the current social hierarchy, and social obligations. They care more about short-term success and gratification than long-term fulfillment.

During the meeting, you get frustrated about the ideas of some of your colleagues and show your disappointment/emotions directly for everyone to see (e.g. you seem disinterested and cross your arms in front of you). After the meeting your colleague Juan takes you aside and explains that some colleagues might take your reaction personally. Why do you think is that?
event.option: Brazilians do not tolerate to show emotions in public.
Brazilians rather show positive emotions in public, however, they hide their anger or temper.
Brazilians usually do not make use of body language or show emotions.

event.message: This is not correct, as the Brazilian culture embraces many emotions.
This is true as Brazilians are known to openly show their positive energy and emotions.
This is not correct, as the Brazilian culture embraces many emotions and frequent use of body language.

event.content: Brazilians set a high value on personal communication. Therefore, the use of emotions in communication should be seen as enthusiasm and emphasis rather than anger or loss of control!

Since the last meeting regarding the marketing campaign, a few days have passed. As you still had a question for Fernando, you sent him an email right after the meeting. However, you have not received a reply yet.
event.option: I call Fernando instead of waiting for another email.
I write Fernando another email in the hope that he returns this one.
I pass by Fernando’s workplace and talk to him directly.

event.message: Calling him directly is definitely better than writing another email.
This may not result in the desired outcome and he might stand you up again.
This is surely the best and easiest way in order to get Fernando’s attention and stress the situation.

event.messageBoxA: Hello Maria, after our meeting this morning you seemed to be a little bit down. I just wanted to make sure that you are okay?
event.messageBoxB: Hello %prename%, well, thank you for asking. You know, I really hoped to get the job as a project manager. Me and Carmen have been working here for this company for so long and this would have meant a lot to me. I surely like Fernando, but still you know… it would be nice to show that I also am capable of taking such responsibility.

event.title: Job promotion
event.description: Pick three factors which could influence a job promotion in Brazil besides social favors.

event.message: Unlike in Western countries, a job promotion in Brazil does not depend as much on performance as it does on social relations.
After you have finished work, Juan asks you whether you are interested in working out a little bit.

event.messageBoxA: Hey %prename%, would you like to play some soccer with us? Some colleagues and I meet each other on regular basis after work. It’s a lot of fun and I’m sure it’s a great chance for you to meet new colleagues.
event.messageBoxB: That sounds great! I am glad to join you.

event.message: Brazil sports are a very important part of Brazil culture. Brazilians are very passionate people and they are no different when it comes to the sports they love.

event.content: To give you an insight here is a short video about the Brazilian sports and dance culture...

During the first project meeting you got invited by your new team members to the monthly department meeting this Friday. Of course you accept the offer and on Friday evening you go to the restaurant 'Tordesilhas' where you’ll meet your colleagues. As you’ve learnt during your first week Brazilian punctuality is flexible, so you take your time on the way to the restaurant. When you arrive Maria and Danilo are already there. You wait for the rest and enter the restaurant. At the table you get a menu which offers a lot of different local dishes. You trust the others and order a dish they recommend to you. Waiting for the food everyone starts to talk about the past week. After a while the waiter brings you your dish while the others are still waiting for theirs. What do you do?
event.option: I wait for everybody to get their food. Having finished, I place the fork and knife on the plate beside of each other parallel to the table side.
I am very hungry, so I start eating when I get my dish and I don’t wait for my colleagues. After the meal I place the fork and knife on the napkin to the side of the plate.

Maria and Fernando already got their dish as well, despite the service being really slow. When they start eating without waiting for the rest, I start eating, too. Having finished, I realize that a piece of food is stuck between my teeth, so I take the toothpick with the one hand, covering my mouth with the other one and start removing it.

events.event:
Advice Correct! As long as the service isn’t extremely slow you should always wait for everybody to get their food.message
BR_advice.jpg

event.message: As long as the service isn’t extremely slow you should always wait for everybody to get their food. To signal the waiter that you’ve finished your meal it is also important to place the fork and knife on the plate beside of each other parallel to the table side.

It is okay to start eating when the service is extremely slow. Otherwise you should always wait for everyone to get their food. Using toothpicks at the table is considered bad manners. It is better to go to the restroom and use it there.

event.content: After you have finished your dinner, which was very delicious, you and your colleagues remain at the table and enjoy the great atmosphere. Everyone is very friendly and asks you about your personal interests including hobbies, sports and social activities. At some point during the conversation Carmen asks:

event.messageBoxA: So, %prename%, tell us, how do you like it here so far? Is the Brazilian culture like you have imagined?
event.messageBoxB: You know, it is wonderful. I have a great time at work and I am very thankful that I got to know you. I definitely have to see more of Brazil. I am eager to learn more about the culture and customs.
event.messageBoxA: Well then, since it’s Carnival season now, you should definitely join us for the parade tomorrow! It is a lot of fun, dancing, music and celebration all around.
event.messageBoxB: Oh, that sounds great, thanks! But I don’t really have any experience in that...
event.messageBoxA: (laughs): Oh don’t worry! Carnival in Brazil is one of the world's most popular events attracting more than 5 million visitors every year. People often wear masks and colorful costumes, and mostly dance to Samba, which is the most prevalent form of dancing here. Let me show you some pictures of last year’s event! I am sure you will like it.
event.messageBoxB: (while watching pictures): This looks like a lot of fun. You know, I am really looking forward to it!

event.title: Lessons learned
event.description: Back at the office after a couple of weeks you write the first report to your boss in Germany. Drag and Drop into the box which values are meaningful in Brazilian organizations.

event.title: Link to documentation
event.description: Drop the element "Documentation" in the first column and click on the new button "Link to Documentation" above the Done-Button.

event.content: Great! Hopefully you've learned a few things about the Brazilian culture and how to behave in certain situations. Don't hesitate to try out the other country modules!

event.description: Please select the square to which you would assign Brazil to!

event.description26: Give it a try! Rate Brazil in each of the 9 dimensions.

event.content:
Shortly before the landing a short video about Brazil is shown on the seat-back screen in front of you.
Just lean back and enjoy!

You have finally arrived in São Paulo after a long and exhausting flight. Danilo, one of the employees of Tyron Technologies picks you up at the airport. You already know this man from phone conversations you had when you were still back home. On the phone, you really got on well. He is already impatiently waiting for you in the arrival hall. How do you think he will welcome you?
event.option: It will be strict handshaking between the two of us.
Both of us just wave hands, smile and say hello in a friendly way.
It could happen that he hugs me, touches my arm/shoulder or gives me a light slap on the back.
He will give me a little kiss on the cheek.

event.message: This may occur, but it could also happen that a person touches you on your arm, shoulder or back in order to warmly welcome you.
This is rather unlikely to happen, since the Brazilian mentality includes a lot of body contact (between hierarchically equals).
Good answer, this indeed may happen.
This form of welcoming someone is indeed common between business people (man - woman, woman - woman) but only if they know each other already.

event.partner: Transport to hotel in co-worker's car
event.content: Danilo, befriended, as is usual with him, helps you with your luggage and gives you a lift to your accommodation. As the airport is a 40-minute ride away from your hotel, you two have plenty of time to have your first real face-to-face chat. While Danilo heaves your suitcase into the car trunk, you set your wits to work in order to think of special topics you two could have a conversation about.

event.title: Transport to hotel in co-worker's car
event.description: What, in your opinion are topics you can address in Brazil? Drag and drop the topics in the appropriate columns. In total 4 topics should be avoided during the conversation.

event.message: Too many personal questions should be avoided during conversation, especially regarding family, income and status in the workplace. It is better to talk about the Brazilian culture like dancing, football or traveling.

event.partner: Invitation by your colleague to pub night
event.content:
Your new colleague Danilo finally drops you off at your hotel.
As you got along quite well during the car ride, he spontaneously asks you:

event.description: Invitation by your colleague to pub night
event.messageBoxA: What about having dinner tonight. You could try some Brazilian specialities. I know a very good place called 'Damas'. Me and my colleagues go there nearly every week.
event.messageBoxB: Thank you for asking, but I am still totally exhausted from the flight and a bit groggy. I really would like to unpack my stuff first and do all that organizational kind of things.
event.messageBoxA: (He looks at you, slowly nods his head, hesitates a little bit and eventually says) Oh, are you sure? ... Well, fine then... See you tomorrow.

option.description: I am disappointed that you don’t want to join.
I wanted to get to know you better.
It is a pity but I accept that you do not come along.

event.message: Correct! Brazilians value socializing a lot, so he will rather not be too happy about you refusing his well-meant offer. Still, it is likely that he will not show you that he feels a little bit offended or he thinks you don’t want to be integrated socially.

event.description: Preparing for your first day at work!
event.message: You have slept well in your hotel bed the first night and had to get up early this morning. You find yourself standing in front of the wardrobe now. It is your first working day and you have to choose what you are going to wear today.

event.title: You have brought all kind of clothes, casual stuff, suits/dresses and sportswear. Select a proper dress for your first day at work.

event.message: Sorry, but this sort of casual outfit is not formal enough and you should avoid appearing in the office looking as if you were on holiday.
Correct. Most offices welcome and prefer an elegant business outfit even though the weather is hot.
A long-sleeve shirt or blouse is okay, but jeans are too informal.

event.content: In the end you decided to wear a nice suit today because you are about to meet the boss, Claudio Pires, on your first day. You arrive at the office at 9:00am where you are welcomed by his secretary.

event.messageBoxA: Good Morning %prename%, I hope you had a good flight. My name is Julia. Unfortunately, Senhor Pires has an important business meeting at short notice, that’s why he asked me to show you a little around and introduce you to your new colleagues.
event.messageBoxB: Good Morning Julia, nice to meet you. Oh, that’s fine. Thanks, I’ve had a pleasant journey. I’m looking forward to meet my new colleagues.

event.content: She shows you your workspace in the huge open space office. In the meantime, the other colleagues Maria, Carmen, Juan and Fernando join you and introduce themselves.

event.partner: Getting in touch with Senhor Pires
event.content: You’re a little overwhelmed and not quite sure how to get in contact with the boss to arrange a new meeting. What could you possibly do to get in touch with him for a first meeting?
event.option: I ask Maria for the boss' email address and write him a polite email.
I ask Juan for the boss' direct dialing number.
I ask Julia, the secretary, to arrange a new meeting with Senhor Pires.

event.message: It is not too common to write emails in Brazil. You wouldn’t especially email your boss, as you might never receive an answer. Best is to arrange a meeting via his secretary.
Juan makes you aware of that it is not common to directly contact your boss in Brazil. He offers you to bring you to the boss' secretary to announce your arrival.

A lot of Brazilian managers have their own office assistant (secretary in the outer office) to receive employees or guests. Right answer! You better let the assistant arrange for a meeting with the boss.

event.content: Oh, it’s already 9:40am and your first meeting with the project team is scheduled for 10:00am! So you hurry back to your desk to study your notes you prepared for the first meeting. On your way you run into Danilo, your Brazilian colleague who welcomed you at the airport. You say “hi” and he greets you back, however, he doesn’t seem to be in the mood to talk to you. It comes to your mind that he might be a little upset because you rejected his invitation for dinner yesterday. What could you do to make up for it?
event.option: When I see him again, I'll apologize for my behavior and explain to him that I didn’t think about the effects it could have, being considered rude. In the end, I'll invite him for a drink.

I have a lot of important stuff to do, so I decide to write an email to Danilo, explaining my behavior and apologizing for it. That should be sufficient as that incident wasn’t that big a deal at all.

In my opinion I didn’t do anything wrong. I don’t feel like I have to apologize for anything. I was really exhausted after the flight and Danilo should know that. I stop thinking about the event and start concentrating myself on more important tasks.

event.message: Danilo will most likely accept your apology. Brazilians in general are very generous and warm-hearted. They will easily forgive you a mistake you made when you talk to them directly.

An apology is no topic that you should put in writing in form of an email. Brazilians prefer verbal communication. That is why you should always try to talk to people directly and avoid writing emails if possible.

In Brazil everything is about relationships. People and their relations are considered much more important than anything else. It is very important for Brazilians to get to know the people they are working with. Therefore, you should take every opportunity you get to enhance your relationship with the locals.

event.content: After seeing Danilo you finally return to your desk. Quickly grabbing your notes, you go to the meeting room. It is your first meeting with the project team. As the decision to send you to Brazil was very spontaneous, you didn’t have the time to talk to the other project members beforehand. Nonetheless, you’ve already been reading through the project information during your flight and you took down some notes and ideas. You think you are well prepared and, therefore, you have a good feeling for the first meeting. What are your expectations for the meeting?
event.option: Everyone will shortly explain their role in the company and afterwards we’ll directly get to work talking about the current state of the project and everyone’s ideas in order to develop a project roadmap.
My Brazilian colleagues will start to talk about their past weekend, soccer... In general, everything but not the project. They seem very eager to get to know me and will ask me a lot of questions.

event.message: Brazilians do not tend to directly start talking about business. It is normal to have a little bit of small talk before starting the real meeting, especially when someone new joins the team. They want to establish a relationship with the people before they start working with them.
Correct! Brazilians want to know more about the people they work with. Before getting to business, they try to get to know their business partners or new team members.

event.content: During the project meeting you got the impression that Fernando is not really interested in the project. He seems somewhat unmotivated which is reflected in his work results. You think that you should find out why he’s lacking motivation and talk to him about his performance.
event.option: I'll address Fernando’s performance during the next project meeting. Maybe the others can give him some feedback as well and together we can encourage Fernando to improve his work.

After the next project meeting I'll take Fernando aside and signal him that I would like to talk to him in private. I'll ask him how the project is going and if there is anything I can support him with.

The next time I see Fernando I'll directly confront him with his poor work results. I'll tell him that his performance seems to be quite weak and ask him if he has any issues with his work where I might help him.

event.message: Try to avoid open, direct feedback or criticism. When you want to give someone feedback you should do it in a private conversation and not in front of the whole team as that causes the person to lose face.
Correct! Talk “between the lines”. Always stress the positive aspects! Make suggestions using the interrogative form. Avoid anything that could damage the relationship.

Try to avoid open, direct feedback or criticism. Talk “between the lines”. Always stress the positive aspects! Make suggestions using the interrogative form. Avoid anything that could damage the relationship.

You have scheduled a meeting with the project team for 10:00am in order to discuss the current as-is-situation and talk about possible measurements and follow-up activities. Unfortunately, it is already 10:00am and you are still the only attendee in the conference room. You start to get impatient and upset because you have quite a few meetings scheduled for the day and you do not want to be behind time after the first meeting! At around 10:15am the first team members start to show up. They welcome you kindly and take a seat. You, however, are not sure how to address your colleagues and stress the importance of punctuality. After everyone has finally arrived at 10:30am, you give the following speech...

event.title: During a meeting
event.description: Create the speech by putting the sentences in the right order via drag-and-drop (5 sentences are correct and 5 are wrong).

option.title: Hello everyone, I have to admit that I am quite disappointed.

event.option: Hello everyone, I have to admit that I am quite disappointed.

option.title: Hello everyone, I would like to welcome you to this meeting today.

event.option: Hello everyone, I would like to welcome you to this meeting today.

option.title: I thought we agreed to have a meeting on 10:00am and now it it already 10:30am.

event.option: I thought we agreed to have a meeting on 10:00am and now it is already 10:30am.

option.title: I am really looking forward to the next couple of months working together with you, therefore I suggest that we all agree to some basic rules, which we as a team need to follow.

event.option: I am really looking forward to the next couple of months working together with you, therefore I suggest that we all agree to some basic rules, which we as a team need to follow.

option.title: In order to make this project a success, it is important that we all commit ourselves to team work. With respect to other colleagues, who might have other meetings scheduled for the day, I suggest, for instance, that we meet deadlines.

event.option: In order to make this project a success, it is important that we all commit ourselves to team work. With respect to other colleagues, who might have other meetings scheduled for the day, I suggest, for instance, that we meet deadlines.

option.title: I would appreciate if you could try to make it on time, so that neither of us is running late for their next meetings.

event.option: I would appreciate if you could try to make it on time, so that neither of us is running late for their next meetings.

option.title: I actually had quite a few important meetings scheduled for today, which I now have to reschedule due to this delay.

event.option: I actually had quite a few important meetings scheduled for today, which I now have to reschedule due to this delay.

option.title: If we have the feeling that we are running late, we inform our teammates.

event.option: If we have the feeling that we are running late, we inform our teammates.

option.title: Thank you, anyway, I am really looking forward to the next couple of months working together with you.

event.option: Thank you, anyway, I am really looking forward to the next couple of months working together with you.

option.title: In this way, we are informed, the other teammates can go to their other scheduled meetings on time and we will give the person who was running late a brief update afterwards. What do you think you about that? Do you have any suggestions?

event.option: In this way, we are informed, the other teammates can go to their other scheduled meetings on time and we will give the person who was running late a brief update afterwards. What do you think you about that? Do you have any suggestions?

event.message: Great! Punctuality is a variable commodity. Meetings can start and finish late. Therefore, try to finish one meeting per day but with clear focus on things. Do not overload the team with activities right away – give time for team building.

event.content: After you have explained your teammates how important it is for you to start on time, they get your point and ensure you that they will consider this next time. Now, however, you seem to face another issue: Instead of talking about the business, your teammates talk about personal things (weather, weekend, etc.). You react as follows:
event.option: “...so anyway, I hope you had a good morning so far. For my part, I feel very lucky to get to experience this kind of weather at that time of year (note: February due to carnival season).”
“...so, considering the fact that we have already lost enough time, I suggest that we get straight to the point.”

“... Unfortunately I see that we have a tight schedule and yet a lot of things to discuss. Hence, I suggest that we try to work our way through and make a lunch break at 12:30pm in order to get some fresh air and catch up a little bit.”

event.message: This answer is quite likely, however, it does not show any appreciation of your teammates.
This way of reacting should better be avoided as it sounds quite harsh and your teammates can feel offended.
This is a very good way to push the meeting forward on the one hand, and on the other hand to maintain a good and solid relationship with your teammates by meeting for lunch.

event.content: Meetings start and end with a lot of small talk. Provide enough time and space for small talk. This strengthens your relationship and improves business.

You are discussing the new marketing concept for the region. When talking about the posters, their layout and content and responsibilities, you notice that most colleagues (especially Maria and Carmen, who have been working in the marketing department for 10 years now and have really good experience in this field) are very eager to contribute and share their ideas among their peers. One colleague, Fernando, who is the nephew of the Brazilian CEO, is not very participating in the discussions. While you are still contemplating who to assign the role of the manager for the marketing concept, your boss, Senhor Pires, spontaneously joins in. After he has picked up the current situation, he decides to give Fernando the responsibility to supervise the project including the work of Maria and Carmen, who have done most of the work so far. You cannot quite understand your boss’s decision. Why do you think your boss put Fernando in charge?
event.option: Senhor Pires does not trust Maria and Carmen due to their lack of experience.
He wants to give Fernando the chance in order to please the CEO.
He prefers men over women in leading positions.

event.message: This answer is unlikely as both women have the trust of the boss and are reliable employees. However, social aspects outweigh performance in many cases. Hierarchy plays quite an important role in Brazil. It is important to show respect to the hierarchically superior. In companies, the bosses often assume the role of a “good parent”. Moreover, Brazil scores high in Collectivism. For instance, an older and powerful member of a family is expected to “help” a younger nephew to be hired for a job in his own company.

Correct! In Brazil it is important to show respect to the hierarchically superior. In companies, the bosses often assume the role of a “good parent”. Moreover, Brazil scores high in Collectivism. For instance, an older and powerful member of a family is expected to “help” a younger nephew to be hired for a job in his own company.

The answer could be true, but Maria and Carmen already have been working for 10 years in the company and they already earned the trust of their boss. However, hierarchy plays quite an important role in Brazil. In Brazil it is important to show respect to the hierarchically superior. In companies, the bosses often assume the role of a “good parent”. Moreover, Brazil scores high in Collectivism. For instance, an older and powerful member of a family is expected to “help” a younger nephew to be hired for a job in his own company.

event.content: While discussing the deadline for the aforementioned marketing campaign, you are rather interested in the long-term outcome and talk about possible milestones during the next 6 months, your team members only consider the next three weeks. After the meeting is over, Juan and you pack your stuff and prepare to leave until a question comes to your mind:

event.messageBoxA: Juan, I know that everyone is working quite hard to make this new marketing campaign a success, however, I cannot quite see an added value, if we are only considering the next three weeks ahead of us? Shouldn’t we make our decisions based on long-term considerations?
event.messageBoxB: %prename%, I can understand your concern, however, I also think that this is a matter of perception. We in Brazil often tempt to make decisions in a more flexible and short matter. This does not mean that we are not well-enough prepared though, in case unforeseen things happen or we need to make changes. We work just as hard as people who plan three or six months in advance, we just set our focus a bit differently...

Short-term orientation describes countries which are mainly focused on the present or past and consider them more important than the future. People with this cultural perspective value tradition, the current social hierarchy, and social obligations. They care more about short-term success and gratification than long-term fulfillment.

event.option: I call Fernando instead of waiting for another email.
I write Fernando another email in the hope that he returns this one.
I pass by Fernando’s workplace and talk to him directly.

This is surely the best and easiest way in order to get Fernando’s attention and stress the situation.

event.messageBoxB: Hello %prename%, well, thank you for asking. You know, I really hoped to get the job as a project manager. event.messageBoxA: Hey %prename%, would you like to play some soccer with us? Some colleagues and I meet each other on regular basis after work. It’s a lot of fun and I’m sure it’s a great chance for you to meet new colleagues.
event.messageBoxB: That sounds great! I am glad to join you.

event.content: To give you an insight here is a short video about the Brazilian sports and dance culture...

During the first project meeting you got invited by your new team members to the monthly department meeting this Friday. Of course you accept the offer and on Friday evening you go to the restaurant 'Tordesilhas' where you’ll meet your colleagues. As you’ve learnt during your first week Brazilian punctuality is flexible, so you take your time on the way to the restaurant. When you arrive Maria and Danilo are already there. You wait for the rest and enter the restaurant. At the table you get a menu which offers a lot of different local dishes. You trust the others and order a dish they recommend to you. Waiting for the food everyone starts to talk about the past week. After a while the waiter brings you your dish while the others are still waiting for theirs. What do you do?
event.option: I wait for everybody to get their food. Having finished, I place the fork and knife on the plate beside of each other parallel to the table side.
I am very hungry, so I start eating when I get my dish and I don’t wait for my colleagues. After the meal I place the fork and knife on the napkin to the side of the plate.
